seriesStmt.title: Ghost hoaxes in 19th-century British news media

sourceDesc.p: All texts in this collection were sourced from British periodical and newspaper archives, transcribed,and encoded. The citation below was provided by the archive and appears exactly as given.

p.bibl: "Not Dead, or No Ghost." Weekly Times, 16 Oct. 1836. Nineteenth Century Collections Online, tinyurl.galegroup.com/tinyurl/55AP33. Accessed 29 July 2017.

projectDesc.p: This document is part of a larger digital collection of stories of ghost hoaxes from the 18th and 19th century London newspapers and periodicals. The project explores the beginnings of mass print media in a metropolitan area at a time when technology and education made reading increasingly common and inexpensive.

The corpus holds 36 individual documents, which reflect a diverse mix of reporting on various hauntings in and around London between 1804 and 1889. The PDF and JPEGs from online databases were transcribed using ABBYFineReader OCR, then corrected and occasionally manually transcribed if document quality necessitated it. After normalization in plain text, all documents were upconverted to TEI XML.

normalization.p: Earlier texts have had some spelling normalization due to errors in OCR. Typographic em dashes are longer than modern em dashes, so all dashes have been normalized to modern em dash length.

quotation.p: All extraneous white space used by printers to avoid overlapping with letters has been removed. All quotes are simply tagged with the q tag.

body.p: ﻿ On Saturday the following extraordinary circumstance was communicated at Hatton Garden:— About six weeks ago a young woman drowned herself in the canal, and the body was owned by a Mrs. Edwards, of Nelson’s Passage, Goswell Street, as that of her missing sister. After the inquest the deceased was conveyed in a shell to the residence of Mrs. Edwards, when the usual preparations were made for the funeral. The whole of the family went into mourning and followed the body to the grave, deeply deploring the untimely fate of their relative. On Friday, however, as Mrs. Edwards was passing through Goswell Street Road, she was almost petrified at beholding what she conceived to be the ghost of her deceased sister. She started back, and after staring at the form for a short time, she ran off, when the apparation pursued her, calling out. Mary, stop; Mary, stop; but this had the effect of increasing her alarm so much, that the poor woman fell down in strong hysterics. When she recovered it was soon proved to her that it was no ghost but her real and living sister. The mystery was then unravelled, it appearing that Mr. Edwards’s sister, had, in consequence of a quarrel with her husband, determined on going into the country, and living with him no longer. The clothes of the deceased have been forwarded to the police. It has not yet been ascertained who the deceased was.
